title: Free Convolution and Generalized Dyson Brownian Motion

# ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS

# SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION
## SI-1: Generalization of the Burgers equation

Let us verify that Eq. (7) follows directly from the subordination relation:

$$
g=\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbf{A}}\left(z-R_{\mathbf{B}}(g, t)\right)
$$

where $\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbf{A}}$ is the Stieltjes transform of $\mathbf{A}$, and $g$ is a shorthand for the notation $\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbf{M}}(z, t)$. By differentiating Eq. (31) with respect to $t$ and $z$ respectively, we obtain:

$$
\partial_{t} g=-\left[\partial_{t} R_{\mathbf{B}}+\partial_{t} g \partial_{g} R_{\mathbf{B}}\right] \partial_{z} \mathfrak{g}_{\mathbf{A}}
$$

and

$$
\partial_{z} g=\left(1-\partial_{z} g \partial_{g} R_{\mathbf{B}}\right) \partial_{z} \mathfrak{g}_{\mathbf{A}}
$$

Thus, by multiplying Eq. (32) by $\left(1-\partial_{z} g \partial_{g} R_{\mathbf{B}}\right)$, we have:

$$
\left(1-\partial_{z} g \partial_{g} R_{\mathbf{B}}\right) \partial_{t} g=-\left[\partial_{t} R_{\mathbf{B}}+\partial_{t} g \partial_{g} R_{\mathbf{B}}\right] \partial_{z} g
$$

which is:

$$
\partial_{t} g=-\partial_{t} R_{\mathbf{B}}(g, t) \partial_{z} g
$$

This concludes the proof of Eq. (7). In fact, Eq. (31) is simply the solution of the previous equation using the so-called "methods of characteristics".

## SI-2: Proof of equation (11)

The key argument leading to Eq. (11) is the following lemma.
Lemma 1. Let $\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{N}$ be distinct real numbers, $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $z \in \mathbb{C}$ non-real. Then,

$$
\sum_{\substack{1 \leq e_{0}, e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n} \leq N}} \frac{1}{\left(z-\lambda_{e_{0}}\right)^{2}}\left[\frac{1}{\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\lambda_{e_{0}}-\lambda_{e_{k}}\right)}-\frac{1}{\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(z-\lambda_{e_{k}}\right)}\right]=0
$$

Proof. Let's introduce the function

$$
f(\xi)=\sum_{e_{0}, e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}} \frac{1}{(z-\xi)^{2}} \frac{1}{\prod_{k=0}^{n}\left(\xi-\lambda_{e_{k}}\right)}
$$

Since

$$
f(\xi) \underset{\xi \rightarrow+\infty}{\sim} \frac{1}{\xi^{2}}
$$

we know that the integral of $f$ over a contour of radius tending towards infinity should be zero. Hence, the sum of the residues of this function must be zero. Fix $1 \leq m \leq N . f$ has a residue at $\lambda_{m}$ which is simply given by

$$
(n+1) \sum_{e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n} \neq m} \frac{1}{\left(z-\lambda_{m}\right)^{2}} \frac{1}{\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\lambda_{m}-\lambda_{e_{k}}\right)}
$$

where we make use of the symmetries of the $e_{i}$. There is also a pole at $z$. Let's denote

$$
P(\xi)=\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\xi-\lambda_{e_{k}}\right)
$$

The residue of $f$ at $z$ is simply given by

$$
\sum_{e_{0}, e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}} \frac{d}{d \xi}\left|{ }_{z} \frac{1}{P(\xi)}=-\sum_{e_{0}, e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}} \frac{P^{\prime}(z)}{P^{2}(z)}=-\sum_{e_{0}, e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n}} \sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{1}{z-\lambda_{e_{k}}} \frac{1}{\prod_{k=0}^{n}\left(z-\lambda_{e_{k}}\right)}\right.
$$

which gives by symmetry of $e_{k}$ :

$$
-(n+1) \sum_{e_{0}, \ldots, e_{n}} \frac{1}{\left(z-\lambda_{e_{0}}\right)^{2}} \frac{1}{\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(z-\lambda_{e_{k}}\right)}
$$

The residue theorem then states that

$$
\sum_{m}(n+1) \sum_{e_{1}, \ldots, e_{n} \neq m} \frac{1}{\left(z-\lambda_{m}\right)^{2}} \frac{1}{\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(\lambda_{m}-\lambda_{e_{k}}\right)}-(n+1) \sum_{e_{0}, \ldots, e_{n}} \frac{1}{\left(z-\lambda_{e_{0}}\right)^{2}} \overline{\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(z-\lambda_{e_{k}}\right)}=0
$$

which proves the desired formula.

# SI-3: Perturbation Theory 

We consider a classical perturbative setting in which a deterministic matrix $\mathbf{A}$ is perturbed by a matrix $\epsilon \mathbf{B}$, where $\epsilon \in \mathbb{R}$ is a small parameter. We are interested in the asymptotic expansion of the eigenvalues $\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{M}}<\ldots<\lambda_{N}^{\mathbf{M}}$ of the perturbed matrix $\mathbf{M}:=\mathbf{A}+\epsilon \mathbf{B}$ in the limit $\epsilon \rightarrow 0$. More precisely, we seek to express the eigenvalues of $\mathbf{M}$ as a power series in $\epsilon$. For each $i$, we write:

$$
\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{M}} \underset{\epsilon \rightarrow 0}{=} \lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}+\epsilon \mu_{i}^{(1)}+\epsilon^{2} \mu_{i}^{(2)}+\cdots+\epsilon^{k} \mu_{i}^{(k)}+o\left(\epsilon^{k}\right)
$$

where $\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}$ denotes the $i$-th eigenvalue of $\mathbf{A}$, and the coefficients $\mu_{i}^{(j)}$ correspond to the $j$-th order correction terms.
To compute these coefficients, we use the theory of resolvents. Recall that if $\mathbf{E}$ denotes a matrix, the resolvent of $\mathbf{E}$, denoted $\mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{E}}(z)$, is defined as the matrix $(z-\mathbf{E})^{-1}$, where $z$ is a complex number outside the spectrum of $\mathbf{E}$. Let us fix $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}$. The Cauchy formula yields

$$
\lambda=\frac{1}{2 i \pi} \oint_{\gamma} \frac{z}{z-\lambda} d z
$$

where $\gamma$ is a closed loop around $\lambda$. Consider $\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{A}+\epsilon \mathbf{B}$. The formula above implies that

$$
\lambda=\frac{1}{2 i \pi} \oint_{\gamma} z \operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{M}}(z)\right) d z
$$

where $\lambda$ is an eigenvalue of $\mathbf{M}$, and $\gamma$ is a closed loop containing only $\lambda$ as an eigenvalue of $\mathbf{M}$. Now, let us expand $\mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{M}}(z)$ for small $\epsilon$, which gives:

$$
\mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{M}}(z)=\mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{A}}(z)+\epsilon \mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{A}}(z) \mathbf{B} \mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{A}}(z)+\epsilon^{2} \mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{A}}(z) \mathbf{B} \mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{A}}(z) \mathbf{B} \mathbf{G}_{\mathbf{A}}(z)+\ldots
$$

By combining Eqs. (46) and the trace of Eq. (47), we deduce that

$$
\mu_{i}^{(j)}=\sum_{1 \leq e_{1}, \ldots, e_{j} \leq N} \frac{1}{2 \pi i} \oint z \frac{\left\langle e_{1}\right| \mathbf{B}\left|e_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle e_{2}\right| \mathbf{B}\left|e_{3}\right\rangle \ldots\left\langle e_{j}\right| \mathbf{B}\left|e_{1}\right\rangle}{\left(z-\lambda_{e_{1}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)^{2}\left(z-\lambda_{e_{2}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right) \ldots\left(z-\lambda_{e_{j}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)} d z
$$

where the $\mu_{i}^{(j)}$ were defined in Eq. (44), and where the $|e\rangle$ denote the unit eigenvectors of $\mathbf{A}$ associated with their respective eigenvalues $\lambda_{e}^{\mathbf{A}}$. The residue theorem allows us to assert that the $\mu_{i}^{(j+1)}$ only include sums of fractional terms where the numerator is the product of $j$ matrix elements of $\mathbf{B}$, and the denominator is of the form $\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\right.$ $\left.\lambda_{k_{1}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right) \ldots\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{j}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)$, where $k_{1}, \ldots, k_{j}$ are distinct from $i$. The contribution from the case where the $\lambda_{k_{a}}^{\mathbf{A}}$ are distinct is precisely of the form given by Eq. (19).

SI-4: Correspondence between perturbation theory and the dynamical system (2)

We recall the functions:

$$
\lambda_{i}(t)=\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}+t \mu_{i}^{(1)}+t^{2} \mu_{i}^{(2)}+t^{3} \mu_{i}^{(3)}+t^{4} \mu_{i}^{(4)}+o\left(t^{4}\right)
$$

where $\mu_{i}^{(1)}, \mu_{i}^{(2)}, \mu_{i}^{(3)}$ are defined in equations (17) and (18), and the fourth term of the perturbation theory $\mu_{i}^{(4)}$ is given by:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu_{i}^{(4)}= & \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2}, k_{3} \neq i} \frac{\langle i| \mathbf{B}\left|k_{3}\right\rangle\left\langle k_{3}\right| \mathbf{B}\left|k_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle k_{2}\right| \mathbf{B}\left|k_{1}\right\rangle\left\langle k_{1}\right| \mathbf{B}|i\rangle}{\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k_{1}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k_{2}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k_{3}}\right)} \\
& -\sum_{k_{1}, k_{2} \neq i} \frac{\langle i| \mathbf{B}\left|k_{1}\right\rangle^{2}\langle i| \mathbf{B}\left|k_{2}\right\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k_{1}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k_{2}}\right)^{2}} \\
& -\langle i| \mathbf{B}|i\rangle \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2} \neq i} \frac{\langle i| \mathbf{B}\left|k_{1}\right\rangle\left\langle k_{1}\right| \mathbf{B}\left|k_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle k_{2}\right| \mathbf{B}|i\rangle}{\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k_{1}}\right)^{2}\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k_{2}}\right)} \\
& -\langle i| \mathbf{B}|i\rangle \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2} \neq i} \frac{\langle i| \mathbf{B}\left|k_{1}\right\rangle\left\langle k_{1}\right| \mathbf{B}\left|k_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle k_{2}\right| \mathbf{B}|i\rangle}{\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k_{1}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k_{2}}\right)^{2}} \\
& +\langle i| \mathbf{B}|i\rangle^{2} \sum_{k \neq i} \frac{\langle i| \mathbf{B}|k\rangle^{2}}{\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{k}\right)^{3}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, we aim to verify that the $\lambda_{i}(t)$ are indeed the solutions of the dynamical system described by Eq. (2), up to order $t^{4}$. For small $t$, the system (2) can be approximated by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\mathrm{d} \lambda_{i}(t)}{d t} & =\frac{2 \kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B}) t}{N} \sum_{k \neq i} \frac{1}{\lambda_{i}(t)-\lambda_{k}(t)} \\
& +\frac{3 \kappa_{3}(\mathbf{B}) t^{2}}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{k_{1}, k_{2} \neq i \\
\text { p.d. }}} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}(t)-\lambda_{k_{1}}(t)\right)\left(\lambda_{i}(t)-\lambda_{k_{2}}(t)\right)} \\
& +\frac{4 \kappa_{4}(\mathbf{B}) t^{3}}{N^{3}} \sum_{\substack{k_{1}, k_{2}, k_{3} \neq i \\
\text { p.d. }}} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}(t)-\lambda_{k_{1}}(t)\right)\left(\lambda_{i}(t)-\lambda_{k_{2}}(t)\right)\left(\lambda_{i}(t)-\lambda_{k_{3}}(t)\right)}+o\left(t^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

or alternatively, keeping all terms to order $t^{3}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\mathrm{d} \lambda_{i}(t)}{d t} & =\frac{2 \kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B}) t}{N} \sum_{k \neq i} \frac{1}{\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}}+\frac{\kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B}) t^{3}}{N} \sum_{1 \leq k \neq i \leq N} \frac{\lambda_{k}^{\prime \prime}(0)-\lambda_{i}^{\prime \prime}(0)}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)^{2}} \\
& +\frac{3 \kappa_{3}(\mathbf{B}) t^{2}}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{k_{1}, k_{2} \neq i \\
\text { p.d. }}} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{1}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{2}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)} \\
& +\frac{4 \kappa_{4}(\mathbf{B}) t^{3}}{N^{3}} \sum_{\substack{k_{1}, k_{2}, k_{3} \neq i \\
\text { p.d. }}} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{1}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{2}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{3}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)}+o\left(t^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\lambda^{\prime \prime}(0)$ is a short-hand for $\left.\mathrm{d}^{2} \lambda / \mathrm{d} t^{2}\right|_{t=0}$. Now,

$$
\frac{\kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B})}{N} \sum_{k \neq i} \frac{\lambda_{k}^{\prime \prime}(0)-\lambda_{i}^{\prime \prime}(0)}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)^{2}}=\frac{2 \kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B})^{2}}{N^{2}} \sum_{1 \leq k \neq i \leq N} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)^{2}}\left(\sum_{j \neq k} \frac{1}{\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{j}^{\mathbf{A}}}-\sum_{j \neq i} \frac{1}{\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{j}^{\mathbf{A}}}\right)
$$

Since

$$
\sum_{j \neq k} \frac{1}{\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{j}^{\mathbf{A}}}-\sum_{j \neq i} \frac{1}{\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{j}^{\mathbf{A}}}=\sum_{j \neq k, i} \frac{\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}}{\left(\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{j}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{j}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)}+\frac{2}{\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{l}^{\mathbf{A}}}
$$

then

$$
\frac{\kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B})}{N} \sum_{k \neq i} \frac{\lambda_{k}^{\prime}(0)-\lambda_{i}^{\prime}(0)}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)^{2}}=\frac{2 \kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B})^{2}}{N^{2}}\left[\sum_{\substack{k, j \neq i \\ k \neq j}} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{j}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{j}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)}+\sum_{k \neq i} \frac{2}{\left(\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)^{3}}\right]
$$

The first sum on the right-hand side vanishes by using symmetry between the indices $k$ and $j$. Finally, by returning to Eq. (52), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\mathrm{d} \lambda_{i}(t)}{d t}=\frac{2 \kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B}) t}{N} \sum_{k \neq i} \frac{1}{\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}} \\
& +\frac{3 \kappa_{3}(\mathbf{B}) t^{2}}{N^{2}} \sum_{\substack{k_{1}, k_{2} \neq i \\
\text { p.d. }}} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{1}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{2}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)} \\
& +4 t^{3}\left(\frac{\kappa_{4}(\mathbf{B})}{N^{3}} \sum_{\substack{k_{1}, k_{2}, k_{3} \neq i \\
\text { p.d. }}} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{1}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{2}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{3}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)}\right. \\
& \left.-\frac{\kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B})^{2}}{N^{2}} \sum_{k \neq i} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)^{3}}\right)+o\left(t^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In the $N \rightarrow \infty$ limit, we expect the functions defined in Eq. (49) to be approximated by

$$
\lambda_{i}(t)=\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}+t \mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i}^{(1)}\right]+t^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i}^{(2)}\right]+t^{3} \mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i}^{(3)}\right]+t^{4} \mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i}^{(4)}\right]
$$

where $\mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i}^{(1)}\right]=0$, and $\mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i}^{(2)}\right], \mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i}^{(3)}\right]$ are given in Eq. (20). Additionally, the formula (22) yields

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\mu_{i}^{(4)}\right]=\frac{\kappa_{4}(\mathbf{B})}{N^{3}} \sum_{\substack{k_{1}, k_{2}, k_{3} \neq i \\ \text { p.d. }}} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{1}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{2}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k_{3}}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)}-\frac{\kappa_{2}(\mathbf{B})^{2}}{N^{2}} \sum_{k \neq i} \frac{1}{\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathbf{A}}-\lambda_{k}^{\mathbf{A}}\right)^{3}}
$$

We then verify that the functions $\lambda_{i}$ in Eq. (57) are solutions of the approximate system above as well as the system in Eq. (2), up to order $t^{4}$.

# SI-5: A lemma 

Lemma 2. Let $\left(\eta_{t}\right)$ be IID random variables drawn from some distribution $\psi(\eta)$, and $\left(\vec{U}_{t}\right)$ be random vectors chosen uniformly on the unit sphere of $\mathbb{R}^{N}$, with $\left\|\vec{U}_{t}\right\|^{2}=1$. Define $T:=\lfloor N \Delta t\rfloor$, and set:

$$
\Delta \mathbf{B}=\sum_{t=1}^{T} \eta_{t}\left|\vec{U}_{t}\right\rangle\left\langle\vec{U}_{t}\right|
$$

Let $j \geq 2$ and consider distinct, orthonormal vectors $b_{1}, \ldots, b_{j} \in \mathbb{R}^{N}$. Then, there exists a constant $c_{j}>0$ such that:

$$
\mathbb{V}\left[\left\langle b_{1}\right| \mathbf{B}\left|b_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle b_{2}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{3}\right\rangle \ldots\left\langle b_{j-1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{j}\right\rangle\right] \underset{N \rightarrow+\infty}{\sim} \frac{c_{j}(\Delta t)^{j}}{N^{j}}
$$

Proof. Using formula (22) or expanding the terms of $\Delta \mathbf{B}$ explicitly, one shows that:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle b_{1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle b_{2}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{3}\right\rangle \ldots\left\langle b_{j-1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{j}\right\rangle\right] \underset{N \rightarrow+\infty}{\sim} \frac{\mathbb{E}\left[\eta^{j}\right] \Delta t}{N^{j-1}}
$$

One can expand:

$$
\left[\left\langle b_{1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{2}\right\rangle \ldots\left\langle b_{j-1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{j}\right\rangle\right]^{2}=\sum_{1 \leq t_{1}, t_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, t_{j}, t_{j}^{\prime} \leq T} \prod_{k=1}^{j}\left[\eta_{t_{k}} \eta_{t_{k}^{\prime}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{k-1}}\right]_{b_{k}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{k}}\right]_{b_{k}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{k-1}^{\prime}}\right]_{b_{k}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{k}^{\prime}}\right]_{b_{k}}\right]
$$

with the convention $t_{0}=t_{j}, t_{0}^{\prime}=t_{j}^{\prime}$, and $\left[\vec{U}_{t}\right]_{b_{k}}=\left\langle\vec{U}_{t} \mid b_{k}\right\rangle$. To evaluate the expectation, recall that a random unit vector $\vec{U}_{t}$ uniformly distributed on the unit sphere can be generated as $\vec{U}_{t}=X_{t} /\left|X_{t}\right|$, where $X_{t}$ is a standard Gaussian vector in $\mathbb{R}^{N}$. In this representation, the coordinates $\left[\vec{U}_{t}\right]_{b_{k}}$ are ratios of Gaussian components to the Euclidean norm of the full vector. Using this representation, the dominant contribution to the expectation of (62) as $N \rightarrow+\infty$ thus scales as $c_{j} T^{j} / N^{2 j}$ where $c_{j}$ is a fixed strictly positive constant. Hence, combined with (61), we find:

$$
\mathbb{V}\left[\left\langle b_{1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{2}\right\rangle \ldots\left\langle b_{j-1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{j}\right\rangle\right] \underset{N \rightarrow \infty}{\sim} \frac{c_{j}(\Delta t)^{j}}{N^{j}}-\frac{\mathbb{E}\left[\eta^{j}\right]^{2}(\Delta t)^{2}}{N^{2(j-1)}} \underset{N \rightarrow \infty}{\sim} \frac{c_{j}(\Delta t)^{j}}{N^{j}}
$$

for $j \geq 3$.
For the special case $j=2$, we start from

$$
\left[\left\langle b_{1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle b_{2}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{1}\right\rangle\right]^{2}=\sum_{1 \leq t_{1}, t_{1}^{\prime}, t_{2}, t_{2}^{\prime} \leq T} \eta_{t_{1}} \eta_{t_{2}} \eta_{t_{1}^{\prime}} \eta_{t_{2}^{\prime}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{1}}\right]_{b_{1}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{2}}\right]_{b_{1}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{1}^{\prime}}\right]_{b_{1}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{2}^{\prime}}\right]_{b_{1}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{1}}\right]_{b_{2}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{2}}\right]_{b_{2}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{1}^{\prime}}\right]_{b_{2}}\left[\vec{U}_{t_{2}^{\prime}}\right]_{b_{2}} .
$$

Taking the expectation as $N \rightarrow+\infty$, the leading term is

$$
\frac{3 \mathbb{E}\left[\eta^{2}\right]^{2} T^{2}}{N^{4}}=\frac{3 \mathbb{E}\left[\eta^{2}\right]^{2}(\Delta t)^{2}}{N^{2}}
$$

Since

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle b_{1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle b_{2}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{1}\right\rangle\right]=\frac{\mathbb{E}\left[\eta^{2}\right] \Delta t}{N}
$$

we can write

$$
\mathbb{V}\left[\left\langle b_{1}\right| \Delta \mathbf{B}\left|b_{2}\right\rangle\left\langle b_{2}\right| \mathbf{B}\left|b_{1}\right\rangle\right] \underset{N \rightarrow+\infty}{\sim} \frac{2 \mathbb{E}\left[\eta^{2}\right]^{2}(\Delta t)^{2}}{N^{2}}
$$

which concludes the proof.

abstract:
The eigenvalue spectrum of the sum of large random matrices that are mutually
"free", i.e., randomly rotated, can be obtained using the formalism of
R-transforms, with many applications in different fields. We provide a direct
interpretation of the otherwise abstract additivity property of R-transforms
for the sum in terms of a dynamical evolution of "particles" (the eigenvalues),
interacting through two-body and higher-body forces and subject to a Gaussian

Interestingly, the appearance of an outlier outside of the bulk of the spectrum
is signalled by a divergence of the "velocity" of the generalized Dyson motion.
We extend our result to products of free matrices.
